title: Practice Test 3
description: This is a practice test 3 for the CompTIA Security+ certification.

questions.question: The MIME specification extends the email message format beyond plain text, enabling the transfer of graphics, audio, and video files over the Internet mail system. S/MIME is an enhanced version of the MIME protocol that enables email security features by providing encryption, authentication, message integrity, and other related services.
What is the name of a network protocol that enables secure file transfer over SSH?
questions.explanation: SFTP (Secure File Transfer Protocol) is a secure version of the File Transfer Protocol (FTP) that uses SSH to encrypt the data being transferred, ensuring confidentiality and integrity.

questions.question: SFTP is an extension of the FTP protocol that adds support for SSL/TLS encryption.
questions.explanation: SFTP is not an extension of FTP — it’s a completely different protocol that works over SSH, not SSL/TLS.

questions.question: A type of cryptographic network protocol for secure data communication, remote command-line login, remote command execution, and other secure network services between two networked computers is known as:
questions.explanation: SSH (Secure Shell) is a cryptographic protocol that provides secure remote access, command execution, and data communication over an unsecured network.

questions.question: Which of the answers listed below refers to a suite of protocols and technologies providing encryption, authentication, and data integrity for network traffic?
questions.explanation: IPsec it’s a suite of protocols that secures IP communications by providing encryption, authentication, and data integrity.

questions.question: Which part of IPsec provides authentication, integrity, and confidentiality?
questions.explanation: Encapsulating Security Payload (ESP) provides authentication, integrity, and confidentiality.

questions.question: A system that uses public network (such as the Internet) as a means for creating private encrypted connections between remote locations is referred to as:
questions.explanation: A Virtual Private Network creates secure, encrypted connections over a public network like the Internet.

questions.question: Which protocol enables secure, real-time delivery of audio and video over an IP network?
questions.explanation: SRTP - Secure Real-time Transport Protocol encrypts and authenticates real-time audio and video streams over IP networks.

questions.question: An encryption protocol primarily used in Wi-Fi networks implementing the WPA2 security standard is called:
questions.explanation: CCMP - Counter Mode with Cipher Block Chaining Message Authentication Code Protocol is the encryption protocol used in WPA2 for Wi-Fi security.

questions.question: A security protocol designed to improve the security of existing WEP implementations is known as:
questions.explanation: Temporal Key Integrity Protocol was created to enhance WEP security without requiring new hardware.

questions.question: Which of the following answers refer(s) to deprecated/insecure encryption protocols and cryptographic hash functions? (Select all that apply)
Which cryptographic protocol is designed to provide secure communications over a computer network and is the successor to SSL?
questions.explanation: Transport Layer Security is the successor to SSL, providing secure communications over a network.

questions.question: Examples of techniques used for encrypting information include symmetric encryption (also called public-key encryption) and asymmetric encryption (also called secret-key encryption, or session-key encryption).
questions.explanation: Symmetric encryption is secret-key encryption, while asymmetric encryption is public-key encryption — the statement in the question reverses them.

questions.question: In asymmetric encryption, any message encrypted with the use of a public key can only be decrypted by applying the same algorithm and a matching private key (and vice versa).
Which of the algorithms listed below are not symmetric ciphers? (Select 3 answers)
Which of the following algorithms do(es) not fall into the category of asymmetric encryption? (Select all that apply)
The term -KEK- refers to a type of cryptographic key often used in key management systems to add an additional layer of security when encrypting and decrypting other cryptographic keys.
questions.explanation: A Key Encryption Key (KEK) is specifically used to encrypt and protect other cryptographic keys.

questions.question: Which of the answers listed below refers to a shared secret authentication method used in WPA, WPA2, and EAP?
questions.explanation: Pre-Shared Key is an authentication method where all devices use the same shared secret (password) in WPA and WPA2.

questions.question: Which of the following answers refers to a protocol used to set up secure connections and exchange of cryptographic keys in IPsec VPNs?
questions.explanation: Internet Key Exchange is used in IPsec VPNs to set up secure connections and negotiate cryptographic keys.

questions.question: Which of the answers listed below refers to a key exchange protocol that generates temporary keys for each session, providing forward secrecy to protect past and future communications?
questions.explanation: Diffie-Hellman Ephemeral generates temporary session keys, ensuring forward secrecy.

questions.question: Which of the following answers refers to a cryptographic key exchange protocol that leverages ECC for enhanced security and efficiency?
questions.explanation: Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman Ephemeral uses ECC to provide secure key exchange with forward secrecy.

questions.question: Which of the answers listed below refers to a solution designed to strengthen the security of session keys?
questions.explanation: Perfect Forward Secrecy ensures session keys are not compromised even if the server’s private key is later exposed.

questions.question: Which of the following answers refers to a public-key cryptosystem used for digital signatures, secure key exchange, and encryption?
Which cryptographic solution would be best suited for low-power devices, such as IoT devices, embedded systems, and mobile devices?
questions.explanation: Elliptic Curve Cryptography provides strong security with smaller key sizes, making it ideal for low-power and resource-constrained devices.

questions.question: Which of the cryptographic algorithms listed below is the least vulnerable to attacks?
